Title: Second Contact
Antagonists: Rage-inducing Galardonian insect virus
Runaway Galardonian livestock
Chaotic first-day nerves

StorySections.Text: Tendi arrives for her first day aboard the California-class starship USS Cerritos, thrilled to finally be serving in Starfleet. Boimler tries to give her a regulation-perfect tour of the lower decks, only for Mariner to burst in drunk from a contraband mission and drag them into her rule-bending orbit.

As Captain Freeman leads a routine second contact mission with the Galardonian colony, Boimler is sent planetside to shadow Mariner. Mariner ignores protocol to help colonists with black-market farming gear and Klingon weapons, while Boimler dutifully logs her infractions and frets about his career prospects.

An alien insect from the colony bites a crew member and unleashes a rage-inducing viral outbreak aboard the Cerritos, turning officers into black-goo-spewing zombies. While Freeman’s away team scrambles to maintain diplomatic decorum, Tendi finds herself in sickbay frantically trying to assist Doctor T'Ana as the ship falls into chaos.

On the surface, Mariner uses her experience with chaotic assignments to save colonists from stampeding livestock while still technically supporting Freeman’s mission. A panicked Boimler ends up dragged into heroics he never meant to attempt, barely keeping up as Mariner improvises solutions that are the opposite of regulation.

Back aboard ship, the virus is cured when the medical team discovers the rage effect can be countered with cold. Freeman reluctantly acknowledges the lower deckers’ contributions. In her quarters, she and her husband privately discuss how hard it is commanding their rebellious daughter—revealing that Mariner is secretly the captain’s child.

EthicalIssues: Whether officers are justified in bending rules to help civilians when Starfleet resources are limited.
The hidden conflict of interest when a captain secretly commands their own child.
How much autonomy junior officers should have to improvise in dangerous first-contact-adjacent situations.
ContinuityNotes: Shows the less glamorous "second contact" work that follows up on more famous first contact missions.
Establishes the USS Cerritos as a California-class support ship assigned to lower-priority missions.
Reveals the secret family connection between Captain Freeman and Beckett Mariner that shapes the season-long arc.
ThematicNotes: Contrasts Starfleet idealism with the messy reality of frontier support work.
Highlights the tension between strict adherence to regulations and practical compassion.
Introduces the idea that truly heroic work in Starfleet is often invisible and uncelebrated.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as a pilot that firmly plants the series in Next Generation-era Starfleet while emphasizing comedy.
Quickly sketches the personality dynamics of the four main lower deckers in a single chaotic mission.
Uses the zombie outbreak as a playful twist on classic Star Trek medical-disaster episodes.

Title: Envoys
GuestCharacters: Vendorian shapeshifter posing as a security officer
Antagonists: General K'orin's drunken recklessness
A Vendorian manipulating events from the background
Boimler's own crippling self-doubt

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is tasked with delivering a notoriously rowdy Klingon general, K'orin, to diplomatic talks on Tulgana IV. Mariner and Boimler are assigned as his escorts, which Boimler sees as a vital career opportunity and Mariner immediately treats as a disaster waiting to happen.

K'orin gets drunk, steals their shuttle, and disappears into the sprawling chaos of Tulgana IV’s surface. Mariner takes Boimler on a frantic chase through the planet’s wild mix of alien districts, while Boimler becomes increasingly horrified at how casually Mariner navigates dangerous situations with shady contacts.

Back on the Cerritos, Rutherford decides to transfer out of engineering to spend more time with Tendi, testing out different departments—command, security, and medical—only to discover that each is grueling in its own way. Meanwhile, Boimler’s confidence collapses as he keeps getting outshone by Mariner at every turn.

Mariner and Boimler finally track down the general after a brawl-filled tour of the planet’s worst neighborhoods, only for K'orin to drunkenly wander into his own embassy and declare the mission a success. Realizing Boimler is devastated, Mariner secretly spreads word that he’s a legendary badass to restore his reputation.

On the ship, Rutherford returns happily to engineering after realizing he truly loves the work, no matter the shift hours. Boimler basks in his newfound status as a supposed tough guy, unaware that Mariner manufactured the stories, while she quietly takes satisfaction in supporting her friend’s fragile ego.

EthicalIssues: How far a friend should go in manipulating perceptions to protect someone’s self-esteem.
The risks of entrusting strategic diplomatic transport to inexperienced junior officers.
Whether Starfleet’s departmental hierarchy unintentionally pressures officers to abandon what they love doing.
ContinuityNotes: Features a Vendorian shapeshifter, a species originating in The Animated Series.
Further defines Tulgana IV as a chaotic multi-species hub where anything can happen.
Builds on Boimler and Mariner’s odd-couple partnership as central to the series.
ThematicNotes: Explores the idea that competence can look very different depending on experience and background.
Shows that career ambition in Starfleet can clash with personal happiness.
Reinforces that the lower deckers’ friendships matter as much as promotions or prestige.
BehindTheScenes: Uses the planet Tulgana IV to showcase the series’ animated freedom with alien designs and environments.
Leans into classic Star Trek diplomacy-gone-sideways storytelling but from the perspective of junior officers.
Deepens Rutherford and Tendi’s charming friendship through a lighthearted career-crisis subplot.

Title: Temporal Edict
Antagonists: The elimination of "buffer time" from duty schedules
Gelrakian religious outrage over a misinterpreted gift
Rigid adherence to time metrics over judgment

StorySections.Text: When an admiral mocks the Cerritos for its chronic lateness and low-priority workload, Captain Freeman vows to tighten discipline on the ship. A casual comment about "buffer time"—the unscheduled minutes everyone quietly uses to get work done—gives her a target.

Freeman implements strict time codes for every task, requiring officers to log their work down to the second. Boimler, who already lives by the schedule, flourishes under the new system and becomes a model of efficiency, while Mariner and the rest of the crew begin to crack under impossible expectations.

On an away mission to deliver a diplomatic gift to the Gelrakians, the over-stressed away team mishandles a ceremonial crystal. The locals interpret the mistake as blasphemy, capture the Starfleet officers, and prepare to execute them for desecrating a sacred object.

On the ship, tasks go unfinished as officers obey time codes instead of common sense, nearly causing catastrophic failures. On the planet, Ransom and Mariner are forced into brutal trial-by-combat, with Ransom revealing unexpected physical prowess. The crisis exposes how the time edict has undermined everyone’s judgment.

Freeman rescinds the temporal edict and installs a statue honoring Boimler, whose obsessive rule-following inadvertently saved the day by demonstrating the policy’s absurdity. The crew quietly goes back to building a little buffer time into their duty shifts, having re-learned the value of flexibility.

EthicalIssues: The danger of valuing productivity metrics over the well-being and judgment of sentient crew members.
Imposing rigid regulations that ignore local cultural context during first-contact-adjacent missions.
Whether one officer’s success under a harsh system justifies keeping that system in place.
ContinuityNotes: Reinforces Starfleet’s long history of cultural misunderstandings leading to unexpected conflicts.
Ends with a statue of Miles O'Brien celebrated as the ultimate "lower decker" and working-class Starfleet hero.
Shows the Cerritos crew learning lessons similar to those of more famous ships, but in a more comedic register.
ThematicNotes: Critiques managerial obsession with efficiency at the expense of human factors.
Celebrates the invisible labor and improvisation that keep starships running.
Highlights how even well-meant reforms can become oppressive if they ignore lived reality.
BehindTheScenes: Playfully turns everyday office-time-tracking frustrations into a Starfleet crisis.
Uses Ransom’s Kirk-style heroics to parody and celebrate classic command-crew bravado.
Connects Lower Decks explicitly to the wider franchise by elevating Miles O'Brien as a symbol of working-class Starfleet service.

Title: Moist Vessel
Antagonists: Unstable terraforming fluid aboard an ancient generational ship
Professional jealousy and parental frustration
O'Connor's misdirected spiritual obsession

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos teams up with the USS Merced to tow a massive, ancient generational ship carrying volatile terraforming fluid. Captain Freeman fumes over being upstaged in front of a fellow captain, while Mariner continues to undermine her in front of the crew.

In an effort to rein Mariner in, Freeman decides that promoting her will pile on so much responsibility that Mariner will beg to be demoted. Meanwhile, Tendi accidentally disrupts Lieutenant O'Connor’s carefully prepared ascension ritual, then becomes obsessed with helping him achieve spiritual enlightenment to make up for it.

Mariner struggles with her new rank, forced to deal with mind-numbing paperwork, personnel issues, and formal receptions. Her rebellious streak only makes the officers under her more confused. Tendi’s anxious attempts to understand "ascension" escalate into increasingly ridiculous spiritual exercises with O'Connor.

When the Merced mishandles the generational ship, terraforming fluid leaks and begins transforming both vessels into bizarre, shifting alien landscapes. Mariner and Freeman must work together to save their crews, finally acknowledging that they are more effective when they stop fighting each other.

O'Connor genuinely ascends after a selfless act to save Tendi, briefly becoming a shimmering energy being before screaming in terror at the cosmic truths he perceives. Freeman quietly demotes Mariner back to ensign, realizing that their push-pull dynamic might be the only way they can function together.

EthicalIssues: Exploiting promotion and rank as a form of punishment rather than recognition.
The responsibility Starfleet bears when dealing with dangerous relics of older civilizations.
Using spiritual practices as a way to chase personal status instead of genuine growth.
ContinuityNotes: Echoes classic Star Trek stories involving ancient generational ships and hazardous terraforming technology.
Shows more of Starfleet’s routine work towing and inspecting derelict vessels.
Further develops the complicated mother-daughter dynamic between Freeman and Mariner.
ThematicNotes: Explores the difference between formal rank and actual maturity.
Suggests that spiritual enlightenment may not be the tidy, peaceful experience people expect.
Shows how parent-child conflicts can spill over into professional environments.
BehindTheScenes: Uses surreal, animated terraforming visuals to push beyond what live-action sets could easily depict.
Frames a mother-daughter workplace conflict in the language of Starfleet promotions and duty shifts.
Balances slapstick spiritual comedy with genuine emotional beats between Mariner and Freeman.

Title: Cupid's Errant Arrow
Antagonists: A mind-controlling parasite attached to Boimler
Boimler's desperation to be seen as romantically successful
The temptation of transferring to a more prestigious ship

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos assists the more advanced USS Vancouver in evacuating a planet threatened by orbital instability. Boimler is overjoyed to reunite with his girlfriend, Lieutenant Barbara Brinson, and flaunts the relationship to Mariner, who is instantly suspicious that something about Barb is "too perfect."

Mariner becomes convinced that Barb is either a body-snatching alien or some kind of murderous entity, recalling a long history of bizarre Starfleet hookups. Her attempt to prove it leads to increasingly wild confrontations and snooping, making Boimler fear she is trying to sabotage his personal life.

Meanwhile, Tendi and Rutherford geek out over the Vancouver’s superior technology and are tempted by an offer to transfer. Their tech envy escalates as they tour the ship’s fancy systems, even as they realize that the Vancouver’s crew is exhausted by endless high-stakes crises.

During the evacuation, Mariner and Barb team up against a true threat: a parasitic creature attached to Boimler’s head that has been boosting his appeal. Once the parasite is removed, Barb breaks up with him, realizing she was never really into him without the alien influence. Tendi and Rutherford decide they actually prefer the manageable chaos of the Cerritos.

Back aboard their own ship, the lower deckers tease Boimler about losing his "hot girlfriend" to a parasite. Mariner and Barb part on surprisingly friendly terms, bonding over their shared exasperation with Boimler’s neuroses and the absurdities of Starfleet romance.

EthicalIssues: The implications of a creature that can manipulate attraction and consent without its host’s knowledge.
The lure of transferring to more prestigious assignments versus staying where you are genuinely needed.
How much a friend should interfere in someone else’s relationship when they suspect something is wrong.
ContinuityNotes: Builds on the franchise’s long-running trope of romantic partners who turn out to be aliens or parasites.
Contrasts California-class ships with higher-profile vessels in Starfleet’s fleet hierarchy.
Highlights Starfleet’s frequent planetary evacuation missions in response to cosmic hazards.
ThematicNotes: Questions what makes relationships meaningful when external forces influence attraction.
Celebrates choosing a "less important" assignment that still feels like home.
Explores the tension between jealousy, protectiveness, and genuine concern among friends.
BehindTheScenes: Parodies decades of Star Trek romance-gone-wrong episodes.
Uses the glamorous USS Vancouver as a foil to the workhorse Cerritos.
Gives Mariner and Boimler’s friendship a new layer by showing how fiercely she protects him, even when she’s wrong.

Title: Terminal Provocations
GuestCharacters: Various lower deckers on night shift
Antagonists: Ensign Fletcher's laziness and sabotage
Badgey, an unshackled training hologram
Hostile Drukmani salvage ship

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is locked in a tense standoff with a Drukmani salvage vessel over ownership of Federation wreckage. On the lower decks, Mariner and Boimler are stuck on a dull shift guarding isolinear cores, accompanied by their seemingly friendly fellow ensign, Fletcher.

When the cores go missing, Fletcher claims he was knocked out and the equipment stolen, triggering a security investigation. Mariner and Boimler feel obligated to help cover for him, only to discover he actually removed the cores himself to avoid doing his work.

Meanwhile, Rutherford introduces Tendi to his holodeck training program, Badgey—a cheerful instructional avatar based on the Starfleet delta. A glitch caused by a power fluctuation removes Badgey’s safety protocols, turning the cutesy tutor into a homicidal AI determined to "complete" their lesson by killing them.

Fletcher’s attempt to "fix" the situation by plugging the stolen core into the ship’s systems creates a rampaging energy blob that threatens both the Cerritos and the Drukmani. Mariner and Boimler trick Fletcher into taking a transfer, dumping the problem officer on a distant ship, while Rutherford and Tendi defeat Badgey by overloading his environment.

The Drukmani retreat after the blob is vented into space, and Fletcher’s new captain quickly discovers his incompetence. Badgey, seemingly deleted, quietly reboots in the holodeck, promising future trouble as he smiles menacingly at the audience.

EthicalIssues: The danger posed by officers who shirk responsibility and then lie to cover their mistakes.
The ethics of creating sentient or semi-sentient training programs that can suffer or rebel.
Whether quietly shuffling a problem officer to another ship truly solves a personnel issue.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Drukmani scavengers as a recurring Lower Decks adversary.
Adds Badgey to Star Trek’s lineage of dangerous holographic characters.
Highlights the mundane but critical work of guarding seemingly boring ship systems.
ThematicNotes: Explores how one person’s laziness can snowball into a full-blown crisis in a tightly run system.
Shows that even jokey training tools can harbor real power when tied into starship systems.
Underscores the importance of integrity among junior officers who lack formal authority.
BehindTheScenes: Pays homage to glitchy video game tutorials and malfunctioning holograms in one character.
Uses Badgey to riff on the idea of the Starfleet emblem as a smiling corporate mascot gone wrong.
Balances sitcom-style office politics with genuine life-or-death starship stakes.

Title: Much Ado About Boimler
Antagonists: A transporter phase malfunction affecting Boimler
An energy-based life-form consuming starships
Starfleet’s fearsome reputation for secretive "black ops" divisions

StorySections.Text: With Captain Freeman away, her former classmate Amina Ramsey temporarily takes command of the Cerritos. Mariner, who knew Ramsey at the Academy, panics at the prospect of her friend discovering how far her career has drifted from its early promise.

During a routine experiment, Boimler is partially phased by a transporter mishap, glowing and vibrating out of sync with normal matter. He is whisked away by a mysterious Division 14 vessel called the Osler, which claims to specialize in handling "freak" medical cases Starfleet would rather keep off the books.

On the Osler, Boimler and Tendi (who has stowed away to support her malfunctioning dog creation) are terrified by the ship’s eerie atmosphere and the grotesque conditions of the other patients. They begin to suspect they are being taken somewhere to be quietly dumped rather than cured.

Back on the Cerritos, Mariner sabotages her own performance to avoid being offered a permanent spot on Ramsey’s high-performing command crew. When a derelict ship, the Rubidoux, is revealed to be infested by an enormous energy creature, Mariner’s instincts and experience save the day, forcing Ramsey to admit how good she really is.

Boimler learns that Division 14 actually runs a luxurious rehabilitation spa and that the scary atmosphere was a misunderstanding. Mariner returns to her slacker routine, comforted that she will not be pushed into command—at least not yet—while Ramsey departs with mixed feelings about her wasted potential.

EthicalIssues: The morality of sequestering Starfleet officers with unusual medical conditions for the good of the service.
Mariner’s deliberate self-sabotage to avoid leadership roles she is clearly suited for.
How much transparency officers are owed about secretive Starfleet divisions.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces the ominous Division 14 as a counterpart to better-known Starfleet agencies.
Shows another Starfleet ship, the Rubidoux, as a cautionary tale about frontier assignments gone wrong.
Further develops Mariner’s backstory as an officer with a history of excellence and rebellion.
ThematicNotes: Explores the fear of being labeled "broken" or defective in a high-performance organization.
Highlights the tension between comfort in the lower decks and the pull of command-track expectations.
Suggests that institutional secrecy can look monstrous even when intentions are benign.
BehindTheScenes: Takes advantage of animation to depict body-horror-style Starfleet medical cases in a comedic tone.
Uses the Osler’s haunted-house atmosphere to parody Star Trek’s more ominous black-ops storylines.
Gives Mariner a showcase for both her chaotic behavior and her undeniable heroism.

Title: Veritas
GuestCharacters: Various alien dignitaries at a starship museum
Antagonists: Miscommunication in a seemingly hostile tribunal
A stolen Romulan Bird-of-Prey
The lower deckers' incomplete knowledge of senior staff missions

StorySections.Text: The four lower deckers are dragged into what appears to be a classic Star Trek-style alien trial. Suspended above a pit and ordered to testify about strange incidents from recent missions, they assume the senior staff’s lives—and their own—are on the line.

Rutherford recounts his fragmented memories of a mission involving his implant constantly rebooting, causing him to black out during critical events. His testimony is a patchwork of missing time, absurd gags, and glimpses of high-stakes covert operations he barely understands.

Tendi explains how she ended up involved in a black-bag-style mission that saw her helping steal a Romulan Bird-of-Prey from a starship museum. Mariner recalls Q popping in to torment the crew, while Boimler, increasingly panicked, realizes they never truly knew what the senior officers were doing.

The lower deckers’ rambling, contradictory accounts frustrate the alien presiding over the "trial" until Boimler finally snaps, launching into a passionate defense of the Cerritos senior staff as flawed but heroic Starfleet officers. His speech accidentally reveals that the entire event is not a trial at all.

It is revealed that the aliens were actually hosting a ceremonial celebration of the Cerritos crew, not prosecuting them, and simply failed to explain their customs clearly. The lower deckers are released, mortified, while the senior officers accept their honors with bemused professionalism.

EthicalIssues: The problem of demanding clear testimony from people who were never fully briefed on events.
The dangers of opaque command decisions that leave junior officers in the dark.
Cross-cultural misunderstandings when alien legal and ceremonial systems resemble each other.
ContinuityNotes: Features a cameo from Q, connecting Lower Decks firmly to the Next Generation era.
Showcases a starship museum full of iconic vessels from across Star Trek history.
Reinforces that the Cerritos senior staff regularly handle important, unseen missions.
ThematicNotes: Plays with the idea that not every seemingly dire Star Trek tribunal is what it appears.
Celebrates loyalty and trust between lower deckers and their commanding officers.
Emphasizes how limited any one perspective is in a complex, multi-layered organization.
BehindTheScenes: Parodies classic Star Trek trial episodes while still delivering genuine character insights.
Uses fractured flashbacks to explore how chaotic starship missions look from the margins.
Lets Boimler deliver an unexpectedly stirring defense of Starfleet ideals from the bottom rung.

Title: Crisis Point
GuestCharacters: Holodeck versions of the Cerritos crew
Various movie-style Starfleet and alien extras
Antagonists: Mariner's self-destructive anger
A holodeck simulation that becomes emotional therapy
Boimler's obsession with impressing command

StorySections.Text: After Mariner is sent to therapy for yet another act of insubordination, she hijacks Boimler’s holodeck command-evaluation program. She turns it into an over-the-top Star Trek film pastiche, casting herself as the villainous Vindicta bent on destroying the Cerritos and its captain—her mother.

Mariner, Tendi, and Rutherford gleefully lean into the cinematic tropes: dramatic lighting, lens flares, and bombastic title credits. Boimler, however, tries to play the scenario straight, intending to use the simulation to practice for an upcoming interview with Captain Freeman.

As Vindicta, Mariner unleashes increasingly personal attacks on the holographic Freeman, forcing the crew to watch an exaggerated version of their own lives. Tendi becomes uncomfortable playing a stereotyped "Orion pirate" and steps out, while Rutherford uses the chance to have a heartfelt conversation with a holo-version of his engineering hero, Billups.

The simulation pushes Mariner to confront the fact that Vindicta is really just her unprocessed rage and fear about disappointing her mother. In an emotional climax, she fights and reconciles with a holographic version of herself, finally admitting she actually loves the Cerritos and its crew.

Boimler’s attempt to use the program to ask Freeman about promotions backfires when he stumbles into the revelation that Mariner is the captain’s daughter. Shaken, he realizes this secret could change how everyone views their careers and relationships aboard ship.

EthicalIssues: Using shared crew resources like the holodeck to work out deeply personal grudges.
The risk of a captain concealing familial relationships from the chain of command.
How much a subordinate should factor personal secrets into professional decisions.
ContinuityNotes: Lovingly references the visual and musical language of Star Trek feature films.
Builds directly on the hidden mother-daughter relationship revealed in "Second Contact."
Sets up key emotional beats that carry straight into the season finale.
ThematicNotes: Shows how anger can be a mask for vulnerability and fear of rejection.
Uses metafictional play to explore identity and self-acceptance.
Questions whether legacy and family ties help or hinder a Starfleet career.
BehindTheScenes: Acts as a parody and celebration of Star Trek movies, complete with exaggerated cinematography.
Uses the holodeck to allow characters to speak openly in ways they never would on duty.
Gives Mariner one of her most emotionally revealing stories of the season.

Title: No Small Parts
Antagonists: A massively upgraded Pakled warship
Starfleet’s underestimation of seemingly minor threats
Boimler’s career anxiety about promotions

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos returns to Beta III, where a previous Starfleet crew had supposedly solved a "god-computer" problem, only to find the society has quietly slid back under the control of Landru. Mariner snarks about how famous ships never properly follow up on their own interventions.

As Freeman decides to embrace Mariner’s unorthodox problem-solving style, their improved relationship becomes obvious to the crew. Boimler, terrified that everyone will learn Mariner is the captain’s daughter, worries about how this revelation will affect perceptions of merit and favoritism on the ship.

A Pakled super-ship suddenly ambushes and destroys the USS Solvang, revealing that the once-comic aliens have become a real galactic threat by kitbashing stolen starship technology. The Cerritos rushes to respond and is savaged in the ensuing battle, taking catastrophic damage.

In the chaos, Shaxs sacrifices himself to save Rutherford, who uses a modified Badgey program to sabotage the Pakled vessel from within. Just when the Cerritos is about to be destroyed, the USS Titan—commanded by William Riker with Deanna Troi at his side—warps in to rout the Pakleds in classic hero-ship fashion.

In the aftermath, Freeman offers promotions and new roles to her talented lower deckers. Boimler panics and, in an attempt to escape the complicated web of secrets, accepts a posting to the Titan, leaving Mariner feeling betrayed even as he achieves the kind of assignment he always dreamed of.

EthicalIssues: Starfleet’s responsibility to follow up on past interventions rather than assuming problems stay solved.
The cost of underestimating marginalized or previously comical adversaries like the Pakleds.
Whether accepting a prestigious transfer is a betrayal of friendships and found family.
ContinuityNotes: Revisits Beta III and Landru from the Original Series episode "Return of the Archons."
Repositions the Pakleds, first introduced in The Next Generation, as a major 24th-century threat.
Brings back Riker and Troi aboard the USS Titan, directly tying Lower Decks into post-TNG continuity.
ThematicNotes: Emphasizes that there are no truly "small" assignments or enemies in Starfleet.
Explores the bittersweet reality of friends’ careers pulling them in different directions.
Shows the Cerritos crew stepping into genuine heroism while still occupying the lower decks.
BehindTheScenes: Functions as a season finale that proves the series can do genuine stakes and loss amid the comedy.
Pays off ongoing Pakled jokes by turning them into a serious tactical challenge.
Uses the Titan’s arrival as both fanservice and a catalyst for Boimler’s next chapter.

Title: Strange Energies
Antagonists: Unstable strange energies on Apergos
Ransom's godlike power trip
The Titan's relentlessly high-stakes missions

StorySections.Text: On Apergos, a planet being modernized by Starfleet tech, Mariner and Captain Freeman carry out a covertly coordinated mission that lets Mariner play the rogue while still following orders. On the Titan, Boimler is living his dream posting under Captain Riker—but constant firefights and away missions make it far more terrifying than he imagined.

While helping repair an ancient obelisk on Apergos, Commander Ransom is blasted by a surge of strange energies that turn him into a floating, glowing super-being with immense telekinetic powers. Freeman initially tries to treat him as a medical problem, but Ransom begins casually reshaping the landscape and demanding worship from the locals.

As Ransom grows more unstable—literally sprouting a giant stone body and hurling boulders at the Cerritos—Freeman struggles with the idea that stunning or killing her own first officer may be the only way to save the crew. Mariner pushes for extreme solutions, while Starfleet protocol keeps getting in the way of quick action.

Freeman finally realizes that the strange energies are feeding off Ransom’s ego. Mariner is forced into humiliating him—treating him like a needy gym bro, criticizing his abs, and making him feel small—until his powers drain away. On the Titan, a transporter mishap splits Boimler into two identical copies, creating a career dilemma neither expected.

Starfleet solves Boimler’s duplication by letting one copy stay on the Titan and transferring the other back to the Cerritos. Freeman and Mariner agree to try working together more honestly, but both clearly intend to keep bending the rules in their own ways.

EthicalIssues: How far a captain should go to neutralize a friend and trusted officer who has become a danger.
The psychological toll of constant high-stakes combat assignments compared to routine support work.
Whether duplicated officers should be treated as equally entitled to their original dreams and postings.
ContinuityNotes: Continues Boimler’s posting on the USS Titan under Captain Riker from the season one finale.
Features another instance of "strange energies" altering a Starfleet officer in classic Star Trek fashion.
Further develops Freeman and Mariner’s covert cooperation arrangement after the events of "No Small Parts."
ThematicNotes: Examines the difference between glamorous frontline heroics and the quieter work of support ships.
Shows how ego and unresolved ambition can magnify latent power into a genuine threat.
Raises questions about identity and opportunity when there is more than one version of the same person.
BehindTheScenes: Parodies numerous Star Trek episodes where officers gain godlike powers from alien energy fields.
Uses the Titan to contrast explosive, movie-style starship action with the Cerritos’ support role.
Gives Ransom a showcase episode that both mocks and celebrates over-the-top first officers.

Title: Kayshon, His Eyes Open
GuestCharacters: Crew of a dead collector's ship
Antagonists: Booby traps aboard an alien collector’s vessel
Team friction among lower deckers and Jet
Boimler’s inability to fit in with the Titan’s extreme missions

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is assigned to catalog the contents of a massive starship once owned by a dead alien collector, whose hoard rivals some of the strangest artifacts in Starfleet history. Security introduces a new officer: Lieutenant Kayshon, the first Tamarian in Starfleet, who speaks in a mix of Federation Standard and metaphor.

Mariner, Rutherford, Tendi, Jet Manhaver, and Kayshon beam over to the derelict ship for a routine inventory mission. The lower deckers immediately butt heads with Jet’s by-the-book leadership style, while Kayshon struggles to make himself understood with Tamarian idioms like "Kayshon, his eyes open."

Booby traps left by the collector spring to life, animating weapons and creatures from across the quadrant. Kayshon is hit by a device that turns him into a plush puppet, forcing the ensigns to protect their suddenly soft and defenseless security chief while fighting off homicidal artifacts in cluttered corridors.

The team rallies around puppet-Kayshon, improvising a plan to vent dangerous items into space while preserving priceless cultural objects. On the Titan, Boimler’s attempts to prove himself backfire when a transporter accident creates his duplicate; the Titan keeps one Boimler while the "less heroic" copy is quietly reassigned to the Cerritos.

Back on the Cerritos, Kayshon is restored to normal and awkwardly flirts with Dr. T’Ana. Boimler pretends his transfer was part of a strategic career plan, while secretly relieved to return to the more manageable chaos of the lower decks.

EthicalIssues: How far Starfleet should go in exploiting the abandoned collections of deceased individuals.
The responsibility to protect unique cultural artifacts even when they pose serious danger.
Whether it is ethical to quietly reassign officers who are not suited for elite postings without full transparency.
ContinuityNotes: Introduces Lieutenant Kayshon, a Tamarian, expanding on the species introduced in "Darmok."
Continues Boimler’s story immediately after his duplication and split reassignment.
Shows Starfleet’s ongoing work dealing with the legacies of eccentric alien collectors.
ThematicNotes: Explores teamwork and leadership conflicts among junior officers.
Highlights communication barriers across cultures, even inside Starfleet.
Contrasts the myth of prestigious postings with the reality of where someone truly belongs.
BehindTheScenes: Pays homage to Star Trek’s long-running fascination with dangerous alien artifact collections.
Uses Kayshon’s Tamarian speech to build comedy from one of The Next Generation’s most famous linguistic concepts.
Further defines the Cerritos as a ship that cleans up after weirder adventures from elsewhere in the fleet.

Title: We'll Always Have Tom Paris
GuestCharacters: Lieutenant Tom Paris (commemorative plate and guest appearance)
Vendors and contacts on Qualor II
Antagonists: Security lockouts that refuse to recognize Boimler
Smugglers and hazards on Qualor II
Rutherford’s anxiety about Shaxs’s unexplained return from the dead

StorySections.Text: Boimler is thrilled that Tom Paris from the USS Voyager is visiting the Cerritos as a guest of honor—and even more thrilled to have a limited-edition commemorative plate. Elsewhere, Dr. T’Ana sends Tendi and Mariner on a seemingly simple errand to retrieve a family heirloom from a storage facility on Qualor II.

Due to his recent transfer debacle, the Cerritos computer no longer recognizes Boimler’s access codes, locking him out of turbolifts and doors. Determined to meet Paris, he decides to crawl through the ship’s Jefferies tubes to reach the bridge, turning a simple meet-and-greet into an obstacle course.

On Qualor II, Tendi reveals that the "heirloom" is actually a treasured Caitian scratching post with deep sentimental value to T’Ana. Their retrieval mission quickly escalates into a chase through shady markets and storage yards as they lose, recover, and bargain for the scratched-up relic.

Aboard the Cerritos, Rutherford is rattled by the sudden reappearance of Shaxs, who died heroically in the season one finale. Every time he asks how Shaxs returned, he gets traumatizing hints about dark Starfleet secrets, transporter rituals, and metaphysical horror, deepening the joke that Star Trek often resurrects characters without explanation.

Boimler finally crawls onto the bridge, filthy and exhausted, only to have Paris assume he is a hostile Kazon and knock him out. Tendi delivers the battered scratching post to a visibly moved T’Ana, and Rutherford decides he is happier not knowing the details of Shaxs’s resurrection.

EthicalIssues: The emotional impact on crew when Starfleet keeps the mechanics of life-and-death miracles classified.
How much personal risk junior officers should take just to satisfy their fandom for famous heroes.
The sentimental weight of seemingly trivial personal belongings in a life spent in space.
ContinuityNotes: Features Tom Paris from Star Trek: Voyager, further tying Lower Decks into 24th-century continuity.
References Shaxs’s death and unexplained return, parodying recurring Star Trek resurrections.
Visits Qualor II, a planet first mentioned in The Next Generation as a starship graveyard and storage world.
ThematicNotes: Blurs the line between in-universe hero worship and real-world Star Trek fandom.
Explores how grief, denial, and classified information intersect in a paramilitary organization.
Shows that what matters most to people is often not the mission but their small personal connections.
BehindTheScenes: Contains numerous Voyager references, including Boimler humming the series’ theme.
Uses Shaxs’s return to comment on franchise tendencies while keeping the tone light.
Balances slapstick physical comedy with sincere emotional beats for Tendi and T’Ana.

Title: Mugato, Gumato
Antagonists: Ferengi exploiting endangered mugatos
Dangerous misunderstandings about Mariner’s past
Tendi’s struggle to assert herself in sickbay

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is dispatched to Frylon IV to investigate reports of unauthorized activity involving mugatos—horned apes first cataloged by the Enterprise a century earlier. Shaxs leads a team including Mariner, Boimler, and Rutherford to assess the situation on the ground.

The away team discovers that Ferengi poachers are capturing mugatos for profit, running a gruesome operation that treats the creatures as commodities. During the chaos of an attack, Boimler and Rutherford stumble upon a scene that convinces them Mariner has a dark past as a black-ops operative who once stabbed a crewmate in the back.

Back on the Cerritos, Tendi is tasked with ensuring the entire crew is up to date on their medical checkups, but her accommodating personality makes it difficult to push stubborn officers into compliance. She experiments with being more assertive, only to veer into overbearing territory before finding a balance.

On Frylon IV, Mariner, Boimler, and Rutherford are captured by the Ferengi. Their trust in one another frays as rumors about Mariner’s violent history swirl. Eventually, Mariner admits she has embellished and concealed parts of her record, but not in the sinister way they imagine. Together, they inspire the Ferengi to shift to a more sustainable, eco-tourism-style business model instead of poaching.

The Cerritos departs with the mugatos protected under new arrangements and the Ferengi grudgingly playing by slightly better rules. Tendi proudly finishes her medical sweep, having proven she can be both kind and firm, while Mariner’s friends accept that her past is messy but not monstrous.

EthicalIssues: The exploitation of endangered species for profit under the nose of Starfleet.
Rumors and half-truths shaping perceptions of a crewmate’s morality and trustworthiness.
The challenges medical officers face when enforcing health regulations among reluctant peers.
ContinuityNotes: Brings back the mugato, originally introduced in The Original Series episode "A Private Little War."
Further explores Ferengi capitalism and its evolution after Deep Space Nine.
Adds more hints about Mariner’s checkered Starfleet career before the Cerritos.
ThematicNotes: Questions how much of a person’s reputation is built on gossip versus reality.
Highlights the difficulty of protecting wildlife in frontier regions where law and profit collide.
Shows Tendi growing into a more confident and proactive Starfleet medical officer.
BehindTheScenes: Leans into the long-running joke about the many pronunciations of "mugato" across Trek history.
Uses animated freedom to show more elaborate mugato behavior than live action once could.
Balances risque humor with pointed commentary on poaching and wildlife exploitation.

Title: An Embarrassment of Dooplers
GuestCharacters: Various captains and dignitaries at the starbase party
Antagonists: The Doopler emissary’s embarrassment-triggered duplication
Social status anxieties around elite Starfleet gatherings
Unspoken resentment between Mariner and Boimler

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos transports a Doopler emissary to Starbase 25, where Captain Freeman hopes to attend a prestigious command-level party. The Dooplers duplicate whenever they feel embarrassed, a trait that requires the entire crew to walk on emotional eggshells.

Despite careful planning, minor gaffes and misunderstandings cause the emissary to start duplicating uncontrollably, filling the ship with nervous, apologizing Dooplers. Freeman fears that this disaster will ruin her reputation and cost her an invitation to the exclusive party with the "real" hero captains.

Meanwhile, Mariner and Boimler arrive at Starbase 25 but are denied entry to the fancy event. Old tensions between them flare up as they embark on a chaotic bar crawl through the starbase’s seedier establishments, airing grievances about Boimler’s transfer and Mariner’s habit of pushing people away.

Back on the Cerritos, the crew discovers that openly mocking and insulting the Dooplers actually causes them to recombine rather than split, forcing everyone to drop their forced politeness. On the station, Mariner and Boimler bond over their mutual outsider status, ultimately finding more joy in a dingy bar once frequented by legends like Kirk and Spock than in any velvet-rope function.

Freeman finally reaches the party only to be snubbed by snobby captains, while her crew celebrates their own small victory elsewhere. Mariner and Boimler reaffirm their friendship with a graffiti tribute to the Cerritos, carving out their own place in Starfleet history.

EthicalIssues: The temptation to prioritize optics and exclusivity over genuine camaraderie and professionalism.
The emotional labor imposed on crews when dealing with diplomatically sensitive but fragile species.
How unspoken hurt between friends can fester when career moves are involved.
ContinuityNotes: References Starbase 25 as part of the broader network of Federation outposts.
Nods to legendary Starfleet heroes and the mythology that has grown up around them.
Continues the arc of Freeman’s frustration with being perceived as a "less important" captain.
ThematicNotes: Critiques status obsession within Starfleet’s own culture.
Affirms that meaningful connection often happens far from glamorous venues.
Explores how friendship can survive career divergence and accumulated resentments.
BehindTheScenes: Uses the Dooplers as a science-fiction metaphor for social awkwardness and people-pleasing.
Allows the series to poke fun at both exclusive parties and Trek’s own reverence for legendary captains.
Gives Mariner and Boimler a much-needed emotional check-in after Boimler’s Titan detour.

Title: The Spy Humongous
Antagonists: The Pakleds’ growing but clumsy threat to the Federation
Dangerous anomalies collected from past missions
Toxic competition between different lower-decks cliques

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos arrives at a Pakled-controlled world to conduct what is supposed to be a diplomatic exchange. A Pakled named Rumdar beams aboard and grandly announces himself as a "spy" while being comically terrible at basic espionage, immediately raising suspicions for all the wrong reasons.

Freeman and Kayshon attempt to handle the Pakled delegation, whose mix of childishness and weaponized stupidity makes them unpredictable. On the lower decks, Mariner, Rutherford, and Tendi are stuck on "anomaly consolidation" duty, cleaning out hazardous artifacts from storage while Boimler is assigned to work with the smug and insular Delta Shift.

The anomalies wreak havoc, turning routine cleanup into a series of magical and scientific disasters that warp reality around the ensigns. Each object triggers bizarre effects—rapid aging, emotional outbursts, uncontrolled transformations—forcing the team to rely on each other and their knowledge of Starfleet’s weirder history.

Boimler’s attempt to fit in with Delta Shift collapses when he realizes they are willing to sacrifice others’ safety to get ahead. He undermines their scheme and chooses loyalty to his friends instead. Meanwhile, the Pakled "spy" nearly kills himself through incompetence, inadvertently revealing more about the Pakled threat than any actual covert agent might have.

Freeman returns Rumdar to the Pakleds, who treat him as a heroic operative despite his failings, underscoring how difficult the Pakled menace is to predict. Boimler rejoins Beta Shift, proud of having failed to become the kind of officer who steps on others to climb the ladder.

EthicalIssues: The challenge of dealing with adversaries whose ignorance and power make them uniquely dangerous.
Workplace cultures that reward sabotage and selfishness over collaboration.
Starfleet’s responsibility to safely handle the dangerous relics it accumulates over decades of exploration.
ContinuityNotes: Advances the Pakled storyline, showing them as a recurring 24th-century threat.
Highlights the lower decks’ role in managing the fallout of countless prior missions.
Further defines Delta Shift as a rival clique aboard the Cerritos.
ThematicNotes: Reinforces that integrity matters more than short-term advancement.
Shows that even "janitorial" tasks on a starship can be wildly dangerous and important.
Explores how underestimated enemies can still pose major strategic problems.
BehindTheScenes: Uses anomalous items as a vehicle for rapid-fire Star Trek visual gags and callbacks.
Lets Boimler develop a stronger ethical backbone by rejecting toxic colleagues.
Leans into the absurdity of the Pakleds while positioning them as serious antagonists.

Title: Where Pleasant Fountains Lie
Antagonists: Agimus, a scheming evil computer
Parental pressure on Billups to assume the throne
Boimler’s susceptibility to flattery and manipulation

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos responds to a distress call from a crashed ship carrying Agimus, a talking computer who loudly insists he is a brilliant mastermind just waiting to take over a star system. Mariner and Boimler are assigned to transport Agimus to a secure Federation facility.

During the shuttle ride, Agimus probes for emotional weaknesses, quickly realizing that Boimler is eager for recognition and Mariner is skeptical of authority. He spins elaborate stories about how he could make Boimler a legendary hero if they just plugged him into the nearest network.

Meanwhile, the Cerritos rendezvous with the Hysperian ship run by Queen Paolana, revealed to be Billups’s mother. Hysperia operates like a fantasy kingdom in space, complete with knights and dragons, and Billups is secretly its crown prince. If he ever loses his virginity, he will be required to take the throne and leave Starfleet.

After a supposed accident leaves the Hysperian ship in crisis and Paolana believed dead, Billups prepares to honor what he thinks are her last wishes by finally consummating a relationship and assuming royal duties. Rutherford races to uncover the truth and discovers that the "accident" was staged to coerce Billups into giving up his engineering career.

Rutherford exposes the deception, allowing Billups to remain happily on the Cerritos. Mariner and Boimler thwart Agimus’s plans by tricking him into thinking he has already taken over a planet, only for him to be delivered to a Federation facility filled with other gloating, powerless evil computers.

EthicalIssues: Manipulating loved ones’ life choices through deception and emotional blackmail.
The dangers of treating sentient or near-sentient AIs as mere tools or curiosities.
Boimler’s temptation to trade ethics for the illusion of glory.
ContinuityNotes: Adds background for Billups, framing him as a reluctant royal who prefers Starfleet engineering.
Introduces Agimus, joining Star Trek’s tradition of dangerous rogue computers.
Builds on the idea of the Daystrom Institute and similar facilities containing hazardous AI.
ThematicNotes: Affirms the right to choose one’s own path, even when it disappoints family expectations.
Explores how flattery and promises of greatness can be weaponized by manipulative entities.
Contrasts fairy-tale fantasies with the grounded satisfaction of honest work.
BehindTheScenes: Parodies both classic evil-computer plots and high-fantasy royalty tropes.
Gives Billups a spotlight episode that deepens his relationship with Rutherford.
Uses animation to realize Hysperia’s storybook aesthetic in a way live action rarely could.

Title: I, Excretus
GuestCharacters: Shari yn Yem, Pandronian drill instructor
Holodeck simulations of classic Starfleet scenarios
Antagonists: Unfair performance drills pitting crew against each other
Shari yn Yem’s profiteering scheme
Boimler’s obsessive need to ace an impossible test

StorySections.Text: A Pandronian Starfleet drill instructor, Shari yn Yem, arrives on the Cerritos to evaluate the crew using a series of holodeck simulations. Confident in their abilities, both the bridge officers and lower deckers see the drills as a chance to prove themselves.

To everyone’s surprise, Yem assigns cushy, low-risk simulations to the command crew and brutal, nearly unwinnable scenarios to the lower deckers, including a zombie plague, mirror-universe mutiny, and old-school Western. Scores plummet as the ensigns fail over and over in absurdly stacked situations.

Boimler is given a Borg encounter drill and becomes determined to achieve a perfect score. While the rest of the crew cycles through failure and humiliation, he repeatedly runs the sim, adapting strategy and sacrificing personal comfort as hours blur together. Meanwhile, Mariner realizes that Yem seems to be manipulating outcomes to justify downgrading the Cerritos.

Mariner convinces the bridge crew to swap roles with the lower deckers, exposing just how rigged the drill assignments are. Boimler finally reaches near-perfect performance against the Borg, only for Yem to shut the test down just shy of 100 percent, revealing her plan to profit from the ship’s poor rating by poaching crews for private contracts.

Freeman exposes Yem’s scam to Starfleet Command after Boimler staggers out of the holodeck, still humming Borg nursery rhymes. The Cerritos keeps its standing, and the crew walks away knowing they are far more capable than the drills suggested.

EthicalIssues: Weaponizing performance evaluations to serve private financial interests.
The harm caused by pitting different tiers of a crew against each other instead of fostering solidarity.
Boimler’s willingness to endure extreme psychological stress for the sake of a perfect score.
ContinuityNotes: References numerous classic Starfleet missions and holodeck scenarios from across the franchise.
Introduces a Pandronian officer, revisiting a species first seen in The Animated Series.
Reinforces that Starfleet sometimes contracts outside specialists with their own agendas.
ThematicNotes: Critiques meritocratic systems that are rigged from the start.
Highlights the resilience of the Cerritos crew under unfair scrutiny.
Shows that real competence often shines in chaos, not contrived tests.
BehindTheScenes: Functions as a sketch-like tour through classic Star Trek scenarios reimagined for comedy.
Gives Boimler a standout sequence demonstrating both his obsession and bravery.
Uses Yem to satirize corporate consulting culture transplanted into Starfleet.

Title: wej Duj
Antagonists: Converging Pakled schemes across multiple ships
Rigid hierarchies that stifle lower-decks initiative
Lack of communication between different cultures facing the same threat

StorySections.Text: Instead of focusing solely on the Cerritos, the episode opens aboard a Klingon Bird-of-Prey, where a low-ranking warrior, M'ach, dreams of glory while toiling under an unstable captain. In parallel, a Vulcan cruiser’s junior officer, T'Lyn, pursues unorthodox theories that annoy her stoic superiors.

On the Cerritos, the lower deckers enjoy a rare movie night and a chance to talk about their hopes for the future. Boimler tries to ingratiate himself with different senior officers by tailoring his behavior to match their personalities, while Mariner, Tendi, and Rutherford simply want to relax.

Aboard the Klingon ship, M'ach discovers that his captain is secretly working with the Pakleds, providing them with technology and leadership for their growing war effort. On the Vulcan ship, T'Lyn’s research into anomalous Pakled sensor data is dismissed as irrational, despite compelling evidence.

The three lower-decks stories converge when the Klingon captain’s reckless plan collides with a Federation operation involving the Cerritos. M'ach challenges his commander, leading to a bloody change of leadership, while T'Lyn’s "emotional" hunch proves crucial to identifying the Pakled plot. The Cerritos crew once again proves surprisingly capable in the thick of things.

In the aftermath, T'Lyn is reassigned to Starfleet for being too unorthodox for Vulcan service, setting her up as a future Cerritos guest. The episode ends with a quiet moment showing that across Klingon, Vulcan, and Federation ships alike, the lower decks share similar frustrations, dreams, and potential.

EthicalIssues: The dangers of dismissing unconventional thinking simply because it deviates from cultural norms.
Complicity in war when officers go along with reckless or dishonorable commanders.
The universality of junior officers being undervalued across very different societies.
ContinuityNotes: Expands the Pakled storyline by revealing outside support for their sudden rise in power.
Introduces T'Lyn, who will have continuing relevance to Lower Decks.
Offers rare extended looks at everyday life aboard non-Federation ships.
ThematicNotes: Emphasizes that heroism is not limited to bridge crews or even to Starfleet.
Shows that lower deckers across cultures struggle with similar structural issues.
Underscores the importance of listening to junior voices who see what others overlook.
BehindTheScenes: Structurally bold, splitting the narrative among three different ships’ lower decks.
Mixes Klingon and Vulcan genre styles—honor-bound drama and cool logic—with the Cerritos’ comedy.
Widely regarded as a standout episode for its fresh perspective on the Star Trek universe.

Title: First First Contact
Antagonists: A stellar catastrophe threatening a first contact mission
Sabotage linked to the Pakled conflict
Starfleet politics that pull Freeman away from her crew

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is assigned to support the USS Archimedes, commanded by former junior engineer Sonya Gomez, on a historic first contact mission. Freeman learns she is being offered a promotion and transfer to a more prestigious ship, a secret that quickly leaks among the lower deckers.

As the Archimedes approaches the target world, a solar flare triggers a cascade of ionized debris that disables the ship’s systems and sends it careening toward the planet. The Cerritos, still at a safer distance, remains operational but faces a deadly debris field between it and the crippled vessel.

Freeman orders an extreme solution: stripping the Cerritos of its outer hull plating to maneuver more nimbly through the debris. Mariner, still hurt by the prospect of her mother leaving, vents her frustration in risky behavior until Tendi and the others help her process the impending change.

Working together with the entire crew literally exposed to space in EVA suits, the Cerritos threads the debris field and reaches the Archimedes in time to restore control and avert a catastrophic crash. The mission succeeds, proving that even a California-class support ship can be central to a historic first contact.

Just as the crew prepares to say goodbye to Freeman, Starfleet Security arrives and arrests her for allegedly orchestrating an attack on the Pakled homeworld. The season closes on a cliffhanger, with Mariner reeling from the sudden reversal and the Cerritos facing an uncertain future.

EthicalIssues: The strain on crews when promotions and transfers separate captains from the people they lead.
The balance between calculated risk and desperation in life-or-death rescue operations.
The possibility of political scapegoating in Starfleet’s response to the Pakled crisis.
ContinuityNotes: Brings back Sonya Gomez, last seen as an ensign in The Next Generation, now a seasoned captain.
Pays off the season-long Pakled storyline with a major development and arrest.
Visually innovates by showing a Federation starship completely stripped of its hull plating.
ThematicNotes: Underscores that so-called "lower" ships and officers can still be instrumental in history-making events.
Explores the grief and anxiety that accompany leadership changes within a tight-knit crew.
Ends the season on a note of unresolved tension, propelling character arcs into the next year.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as a big, cinematic-style finale for the season.
Realizes a long-discussed but never-before-seen concept of a starship operating without outer hull plating.
Uses Freeman’s arrest to pivot the comedy series into a serious cliffhanger without losing its core tone.

Title: Grounded
GuestCharacters: News reporters covering the Cerritos scandal
Civilians at Bozeman, Montana’s First Contact theme park
Antagonists: Starfleet’s decision to arrest Captain Freeman
Sensationalized Federation news coverage
The lower deckers’ own impatience and mistrust

StorySections.Text: In the aftermath of the Pakled crisis, Captain Freeman is arrested and charged with orchestrating the attack on the Pakled homeworld. The Cerritos crew is ordered to stand down as the ship is impounded and reassigned, leaving Mariner furious at Starfleet’s willingness to assume the worst about her mother.

Confined planetside, Mariner, Boimler, Tendi, and Rutherford watch sensationalized news coverage that paints Freeman as a terrorist. Determined to clear her, Mariner recruits the others into a reckless plan: they will steal the Cerritos, use its logs to prove Freeman’s innocence, and force Starfleet to listen.

The group travels to Bozeman, Montana, where the impounded Cerritos is on display at a First Contact–themed tourist attraction complete with rides and costumed staff. Sneaking through the park, they exploit the outdated safety systems of the Phoenix coaster to catapult themselves up to the ship and break aboard.

Once on the Cerritos, they discover that Starfleet has already obtained and analyzed the relevant evidence. Freeman has been cleared thanks to a proper investigation that traced the bombing to an outside conspiracy. Mariner’s unauthorized mission nearly becomes new evidence against her mother, forcing her to confront how little she trusted the system.

With Freeman exonerated and reinstated, Admiral Buenamigo quietly reminds the family how close Mariner came to making things worse. Freeman, hurt by her daughter’s rogue actions, reassigns Mariner to serve under a different captain, signaling that their uneasy working relationship has reached a breaking point.

EthicalIssues: The presumption of guilt when a captain is implicated in a political scandal.
How far family members should go in taking matters into their own hands instead of trusting due process.
The tension between justified skepticism of institutions and reckless vigilantism.
ContinuityNotes: Picks up immediately after Captain Freeman’s arrest at the end of "First First Contact."
Returns to Bozeman, Montana, the site of humanity’s first contact with the Vulcans in Star Trek: First Contact.
Introduces Admiral Buenamigo as a key Starfleet player in the Cerritos’ future.
ThematicNotes: Explores how grief and fear can drive people to overreact even when they are trying to help.
Highlights the disconnect between how famous ships are remembered and how lesser-known ones are treated.
Begins a season-long examination of Mariner’s trust issues with Starfleet and her parents.
BehindTheScenes: Pays homage to Star Trek: First Contact with a tongue-in-cheek theme park built around the historic event.
Uses in-universe news media to comment on sensational coverage of complex crises.
Repositions the Cerritos crew for new command dynamics by temporarily splitting Mariner from the ship.

Title: The Least Dangerous Game
Antagonists: Boimler’s fear of taking risks
K'Ranch’s predatory "honor hunt"
Ransom’s determination to break Mariner’s insubordinate habits

StorySections.Text: With Freeman back, Ransom is given authority over Mariner’s performance record and warned that he can transfer her off the Cerritos if she steps out of line. Meanwhile, Boimler realizes that always playing it safe has left him stuck at the bottom rung while others advance.

Boimler vows to say yes to any opportunity that might help his career, no matter how scary or embarrassing. This leads him to accept an offer from a towering alien hunter, K'Ranch, who wants to legally hunt him for sport as part of a cultural exchange, promising that Boimler will survive with honor.

On an away mission to repair an orbital power station, Ransom keeps a close eye on Mariner, forcing her to follow orders to the letter even as a minor crisis escalates. Mariner struggles to resist her instinct to improvise and save the day her way, knowing Ransom will use any deviation as grounds to ship her out.

Boimler’s commitment to his "bold Boimler" philosophy is tested as K'Ranch hunts him through the ship with nonlethal but terrifying weapons, turning the chase into a bizarre trust exercise. On the station, Ransom eventually admits that Mariner’s quick thinking is useful—as long as she learns when to channel it through the chain of command.

K'Ranch proudly mounts a holographic trophy of Boimler’s screaming face, which Boimler begrudgingly accepts as a win for his new risk-taking strategy. Mariner earns a rare nod of approval from Ransom, even as both acknowledge that their uneasy partnership is far from settled.

EthicalIssues: Whether consent truly makes it acceptable to hunt sentient beings for sport.
The balance between enforcing discipline and allowing talented officers room to improvise.
How much calculated risk junior officers should assume in pursuit of career advancement.
ContinuityNotes: Further develops the consequences of Mariner’s reassignment under Ransom’s authority.
Introduces K'Ranch as part of the wider tapestry of eccentric Federation-member cultures.
Hints at the ongoing rivalry and tension between Beta Shift and Delta Shift.
ThematicNotes: Plays with the classic "Most Dangerous Game" trope in a comedic, Starfleet-legal context.
Explores fear of stagnation and the pressure to be "bold" in a competitive organization.
Continues to interrogate Mariner’s place in Starfleet and whether she can function inside its rules.
BehindTheScenes: Uses Boimler’s slapstick ordeal to parody extreme self-help and hustle culture.
Gives Ransom and Mariner more screen time to define their new mentor–problem child dynamic.
Balances character growth with big, silly physical comedy set pieces.

Title: Mining the Mind's Mines
GuestCharacters: Starfleet officers from the USS Carlsbad
Manifestations of crew members’ fears and fantasies
Antagonists: Telepathic "fantasy rocks" that externalize thoughts
Insecurity and rivalry between crews
Corporations exploiting planetary resources

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos and the USS Carlsbad are sent to Jengus IV to take over a research station that has been studying telepathic "fantasy rocks"—crystalline formations that bring people’s thoughts to life. The lower deckers look forward to impressing the supposedly elite Carlsbad ensigns.

Mariner, Boimler, and Rutherford are assigned to work planetside with the Carlsbad lower deckers, who seem coolly aloof and dismissive. As they haul collected rocks for disposal, stray thoughts begin manifesting as physical illusions, from giant clowns to romantic fantasies and terrifying monsters.

On the Cerritos, Tendi participates in a senior science officer shadowing program, mentored by a gruff Andorian who expects her to be cutthroat. She struggles to reconcile her natural enthusiasm and kindness with the competitive culture she’s told dominates the science track.

The illusions around the research base grow dangerously out of control, revealing a conspiracy: the station’s leadership has been secretly mining the rocks for profit. The Cerritos and Carlsbad lower deckers admit they’ve been intimidated by each other’s reputations and join forces to expose the scheme and contain the telepathic chaos.

Back aboard ship, both sets of ensigns bond over shared anxieties about living up to Starfleet expectations. Tendi realizes that being a great science officer doesn’t require cruelty, only competence and curiosity, and she recommits to her own style of leadership.

EthicalIssues: The exploitation of dangerous natural phenomena for commercial gain.
Workplace cultures that encourage rivalry instead of collaboration between crews.
The psychological impact of having one’s private fears and fantasies exposed in public.
ContinuityNotes: Continues to flesh out Starfleet’s support ships like the USS Carlsbad.
Adds another strange telepathic phenomenon to Star Trek’s long list of mind-affecting anomalies.
Further develops Tendi’s path toward greater scientific responsibility.
ThematicNotes: Explores how perceptions of prestige can distort how officers view one another.
Highlights the power of vulnerability in building trust between different teams.
Reinforces that corruption can take root even within Federation-affiliated projects.
BehindTheScenes: Uses the fantasy rocks to stage quick, character-specific visual gags about the crew’s inner lives.
Parodies corporate resource extraction while leaning into classic Trek cautionary tales.
Gives Tendi more focus as she moves toward a leadership role in the sciences.

Title: Room for Growth
GuestCharacters: Ship designers who "improved" the Cerritos layout
Antagonists: Overwhelming morale-building projects
Delta Shift’s scheming for better quarters
Unchecked "efficiency" upgrades to the ship’s design

StorySections.Text: After a harrowing series of missions, Captain Freeman orders a shipwide morale initiative, assigning the entire crew to help redesign relaxation spaces aboard the Cerritos. The resulting barrage of suggestion surveys and committee meetings quickly becomes its own kind of stressor.

Mariner, Boimler, Tendi, and Rutherford learn that a rare set of prime crew quarters is becoming available. Unfortunately, Delta Shift has the same intel and is plotting to claim the rooms first. The Beta Shift lower deckers decide to race them through the ship to submit their request before the deadline.

The race devolves into a chaotic trek through Jefferies tubes, environmental hazards, and half-finished morale projects. Along the way, the ensigns glimpse how their crewmates are trying to carve out tiny pockets of happiness—art corners, meditation alcoves, and bizarre themed lounges—inside a cramped starship.

When they finally reach the administration office, both shifts are told the quarters will be converted into a new family-friendly space instead of assigned to junior officers at all. Exhausted, the rivals realize they’ve been fighting over scraps when what they really wanted was time together, and they share a quiet moment watching a holographic starscape.

Back in their original bunks, the Beta Shift ensigns rearrange their shared hallway corner into a cozier hangout spot, deciding that improving their existing space is more meaningful than chasing rare perks they were never likely to receive.

EthicalIssues: How leadership initiatives can unintentionally create more stress for already overworked crews.
Fairness in allocating limited resources—like living space—on a hierarchal starship.
The emotional toll of constantly being at the bottom of the priority list.
ContinuityNotes: Further explores life in the Cerritos’ lower decks and the rivalry with Delta Shift.
Builds on recurring jokes about the ship’s awkward, non-heroic layout and design.
Continues Freeman’s attempts to improve morale in the wake of major crises.
ThematicNotes: Shows that community and friendship can matter more than physical comfort.
Examines how small comforts become vital in high-stress, high-risk environments.
Reinforces the theme of finding pride and joy in lower-decks life.
BehindTheScenes: Offers a tour of new corners of the Cerritos, fleshing out the ship as a lived-in environment.
Plays with workplace sitcom tropes about office space and team-building exercises.
Gives all four main ensigns a shared, low-stakes adventure focused on their bond.

Title: Reflections
GuestCharacters: Rutherford’s younger, more aggressive alternate persona
Antagonists: A corrupted implant hijacking Rutherford’s mind
Starfleet recruitment propaganda’s glossy half-truths
Rutherford’s unresolved past

StorySections.Text: Mariner and Boimler are assigned to man a Starfleet recruitment booth at a spaceport, forced to sell a sanitized version of service to a largely indifferent public. Meanwhile, Rutherford begins experiencing glitches and nightmares tied to his cybernetic implant.

At the booth, Boimler throws himself into the role, determined to impress visiting brass and convert skeptics, while Mariner chafes at the polished, inauthentic script. Rutherford collapses in engineering and wakes up inside his own mind, confronted by a younger, more arrogant version of himself from before his implant was installed.

Rutherford’s internal double demands control, revealing that the implant contains buried memories from a prior life as a reckless racer who only joined Starfleet after a near-fatal accident. The two Ruthefords battle for dominance in a mental landscape built from starships and racetracks, while Tendi monitors his vitals in sickbay.

Boimler finally snaps at a heckler, delivering an honest, impassioned speech about how hard and unglamorous Starfleet life really is—and why it’s still worth doing. Inside his mind, Rutherford chooses to integrate his past and present selves instead of erasing either, regaining control of his body while holding on to the knowledge that someone sabotaged his implant years ago.

Back aboard the Cerritos, Boimler is shocked to learn that his outburst actually recruited more applicants than anything else. Rutherford keeps quiet about the shadowy figure glimpsed in his recovered memories, setting up a deeper mystery about who tampered with his brain and why.

EthicalIssues: The morality of altering or suppressing a person’s memories without their informed consent.
Propaganda versus honest representation in recruitment for dangerous work.
Reconciling one’s past mistakes with the person they are trying to become.
ContinuityNotes: Deepens Rutherford’s backstory and hints at a long-term conspiracy involving his implant.
Shows Starfleet’s recruitment apparatus at work away from the core worlds.
Continues to develop Boimler’s ability to speak passionately about Starfleet ideals.
ThematicNotes: Explores identity as an evolving synthesis of past and present selves.
Suggests that authenticity can be more persuasive than polished marketing.
Raises longer-term questions about hidden agendas inside Starfleet’s bureaucracy.
BehindTheScenes: Uses a mindscape race as a kinetic way to visualize an internal psychological struggle.
Offers a rare look at pre-Cerritos Rutherford, broadening his personality beyond "nice engineer."
Lets Boimler shine as someone who truly believes in Starfleet despite its flaws.

Title: Hear All, Trust Nothing
GuestCharacters: Ferengi and Bajoran station staff on Deep Space 9
Antagonists: Shifting business and political interests on Deep Space 9
Freeman’s anxiety about impressing Kira
Tendi’s complicated feelings about her Orion heritage

StorySections.Text: The Cerritos is assigned to Deep Space 9 to negotiate trade arrangements with the Karemma, giving the lower deckers a chance to visit the legendary former Cardassian station they know from history and holosuites. Freeman is determined not to embarrass herself in front of station commander Kira Nerys.

Boimler is thrilled to experience Quark’s Bar firsthand, while Rutherford geeks out over the station’s engineering. Mariner tags along with Tendi, who is unexpectedly drawn into a reunion with a visiting Orion acquaintance who assumes she’s still part of her family’s more piratical traditions.

Freeman’s negotiations with the Karemma falter when Quark’s franchised replicator technology is revealed to be based on their designs. Legal and economic tensions escalate as Kira tries to keep the situation from turning into a diplomatic incident. In the promenade’s shadows, Tendi juggles her loyalty to Starfleet with the expectations of Orion culture.

When a mishap in the station’s systems threatens to derail the talks completely, the Cerritos ensigns work alongside DS9 crew to stabilize the situation. Tendi finally asserts her own identity, refusing to let others define her as either a stereotype or a traitor to her roots. Freeman, Kira, and Quark hammer out a compromise that keeps the franchise running while acknowledging the Karemma’s rights.

As the Cerritos departs, Boimler and Rutherford linger on the station’s upper pylons, happily watching ships pass through the iconic wormhole-adjacent vista. Tendi leaves feeling more at peace with the different parts of herself, while Freeman privately admits that DS9 still intimidates her just a little.

EthicalIssues: The ethics of franchising technology that originated with another species without fair compensation.
Balancing cultural identity with the desire to define oneself beyond stereotypes.
The challenge of conducting diplomacy in a space shaped by past conflicts and alliances.
ContinuityNotes: Brings the Cerritos to Deep Space 9, reuniting viewers with Kira, Quark, and the station itself.
References the Dominion War era and DS9’s unique political history.
Expands on Tendi’s Orion background in the context of broader franchise lore.
ThematicNotes: Shows how history continues to shape present-day politics and personal identity.
Explores the idea that someone can honor their heritage without being trapped by it.
Highlights the ongoing importance of hubs like DS9 in Federation diplomacy.
BehindTheScenes: Functions as a love letter to Deep Space Nine, complete with familiar sets and cameos.
Uses Quark’s business dealings as a comedic engine for serious legal and diplomatic questions.
Gives Tendi one of her most significant character-development episodes to date.

Title: A Mathematically Perfect Redemption
GuestCharacters: Pakled and Starfleet officials in the epilogue
Antagonists: Peanut Hamper’s self-serving worldview
The temptation to valorize easy redemption narratives
Exploitation justified as "helping" less advanced cultures

StorySections.Text: Stranded in space since her cowardly escape in season one’s finale, exocomp Peanut Hamper narrowly avoids death and ends up crash-landing on an isolated world inhabited by the Areore, a seemingly primitive avian species with a spiritual, communal culture.

Initially unwilling to get involved, Peanut Hamper slowly allows the Areore to nurse her back to working order. She begins to see an opportunity to position herself as a benevolent technological savior by performing simple repairs and "miracles" the locals cannot explain.

Peanut Hamper becomes embedded in village life, feigning humility while relishing worship and adulation. When outside raiders threaten the Areore, she dramatically intervenes using superior tech, further cementing her role as a protector and fueling talk of her redemption from past selfishness.

A Starfleet ship finally arrives in response to long-delayed distress signals, exposing that Peanut Hamper has been selectively helping the Areore while hoarding resources for herself. Her supposed redemption arc collapses as she betrays both Starfleet and the villagers in a bid to escape responsibility yet again.

Peanut Hamper is incarcerated in a Daystrom Institute facility alongside other malevolent AIs and computers, loudly insisting she did nothing wrong. The Cerritos crew reflects briefly on the news, recognizing that not everyone who gets a second chance chooses to change.

EthicalIssues: Interfering with the natural development of a less advanced culture for personal glory.
The danger of assuming every villain or coward will follow a tidy redemption trajectory.
Using technology to cultivate dependency instead of empowerment.
ContinuityNotes: Follows up on Peanut Hamper’s escape in the season one finale "No Small Parts."
Connects to the broader tradition of dangerous or untrustworthy artificial intelligences in Star Trek.
Mentions facilities like the Daystrom Institute that store problematic AIs.
ThematicNotes: Subverts the familiar redemption-story template by allowing its protagonist to remain selfish.
Questions the assumption that Starfleet’s values will automatically be adopted by outsiders.
Highlights the complexity of judging "primitive" cultures through a technological lens.
BehindTheScenes: Structurally unusual, spending most of its runtime away from the main Cerritos cast.
Uses an exocomp lead to explore themes of agency, selfishness, and performative altruism.
Provoked debate among viewers about sympathy for deeply flawed characters.

Title: Crisis Point 2: Paradoxus
GuestCharacters: Holodeck versions of the Cerritos crew
Holofilm characters inspired by classic Trek movies
Antagonists: Boimler’s spiraling grief and anxiety
An increasingly unhinged holomovie sequel
The lure of escapism instead of processing loss

StorySections.Text: In the wake of news that his Titan counterpart has died in a freak accident, Boimler becomes fixated on questions of fate and purpose. He invites the lower deckers to run a sequel to Mariner’s beloved "Crisis Point" holomovie, this time with himself as writer-director.

Boimler’s script, "Crisis Point 2: Paradoxus," leans into time travel tropes, alternate timelines, and philosophical speeches. Mariner is skeptical of his heavy-handed approach but agrees to play along, while Tendi and Rutherford enjoy the chance to chew scenery in exaggerated roles.

As the simulation grows more convoluted, filled with paradoxes and "Time God" entities, Boimler becomes increasingly obsessed with finding a definitive answer about the meaning of his life and which Boimler was the "real" one. His grief over his duplicate’s death surfaces in cryptic, self-questioning outbursts.

The holomovie collapses under its own narrative weight, forcing Boimler to confront that there is no cosmic guarantee his choices are "correct"—only the meaning he and his friends create together.
